Award.AwardTitle: RAPID: Graduate student experiences of support and stress during the COVID-19 pandemic
Award.AbstractNarration: RAPID: Understanding Graduate Student Experiences of Support and Stress During the COVID-19 Pandemic <br/><br/>COVID-19 has rapidly upended graduate students’ learning, research, and teaching. Carefully crafted career paths that often require substantial investments by both students and their institutions have been placed at risk due to newly imposed challenges. These challenges include limited access to classrooms and labs, disruption to current and planned collaborations, increased stress and anxiety, and new responsibilities for children and other family members. This impact is particularly acute for graduate students with marginalized identities (e.g., students of color, low-income students) who are often already struggling with existing inequalities. To compound matters, these hardships confront a graduate student population that multiple studies suggest was already facing a mental health crisis. If graduate students do not feel supported during this critical period, the U.S. may suffer a dramatic decline in the effectiveness and inclusiveness of its graduate-level training, resulting in long-term negative impacts on the U.S. scientific knowledge base, society, and the broader U.S. economy. This National Science Foundation Rapid Response Research (RAPID) award to Montana State University, Iowa State University, and Texas A&M-Commerce will support research on: postsecondary institutional policies and practices that are designed to help graduate students feel supported during the COVID-19 pandemic and the influence of these efforts on graduate student educational and career decision-making. The study will contribute to a research base for graduate school administrators and faculty about how to immediately help graduate students during a crisis, as well as what strategies might be most effective for supporting graduate students in STEM fields and more broadly as they make degree and career-related decisions as society emerges from the crisis. <br/><br/>The project is a multi-institution, two-phase explanatory mixed method study of graduate students’ experiences during the COVID-19 pandemic, their perceptions of institutional support, and near-term impact of this support on educational and career decision-making. The research team will leverage existing institutional higher education networks to solicit the participation of 15 institutions and disseminate questionnaires to 30,000 graduate students in late spring/early summer 2020. The research is informed by scholarship on trauma and disaster response. The survey, which will include validated trauma scales that measure post-traumatic stress disorder-like symptoms, anxiety, and depression, will be designed by an interdisciplinary team that includes trauma and mental health experts. Team members will then conduct virtual focus groups using semi-structured qualitative interview protocols to explore students’ experiences and reactions to the COVID-19 pandemic in-depth, and how these experiences relate to their identities, persistence, and career aspirations. Researchers will integrate both quantitative and qualitative data to further interpret, explain, and provide new insights to understanding graduate student experiences during the COVID-19 pandemic. Analyses will pay particular attention to student experiences related to race, class, gender, and other socio-demographic factors. Multiple efforts will be made at each stage to recruit and support participation of underrepresented minority STEM graduate students in the study. Results of the research will be disseminated through peer reviewed scholarship, a white paper, and workshops providing graduate college leadership and STEM faculty with research-based guidelines on how to support the broadest range of their graduate students during a time of crisis. <br/><br/>This Rapid Response Research (RAPID) award is made by the Innovations in Graduate Education (IGE) program in the Division of Graduate Education/Directorate of Education and Human Resources using funds from the Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security (CARES) Act.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The COVID-19 pandemic has influenced a variety of graduate student populations, across student identities, fields of study, and degree programs—from master’s students to those pursuing doctorates or other professional degrees—upending their learning, teaching, and research. We conducted a multi-institution mixed-methods study to better understand graduate students’ experiences during the pandemic and the relationship of those experiences to their educational and career plans. Based on our results, we suggest postsecondary institutional policies and practices designed to help graduate students feel supported during the COVID-19 pandemic as it evolves over time and to contribute to a research base for graduate school administrators and faculty about how to help graduate students both immediately and longer-term during a protracted crisis. 

Our study included graduate student participants from 12 universities across the United States. Of more than 60,000 invited graduate students, approximately 3,500 participated in a survey of graduate students’ experiences during June and July 2020. We conducted focus group interviews with 56 of these students in August 2020. We re-surveyed a subset of the initial survey respondents a year later in June 2021 about their experiences of the previous academic year, yielding approximately 880 participants.  

Our key findings from Summer 2020 suggest that U.S. graduate students were experiencing significant and overlapping challenges. Approximately one-third of graduate students reported significant PTSS symptoms, moderate or higher levels of anxiety, and moderate or higher levels of depression. Approximately one-fourth of students also reported some levels of food and housing insecurity. Black and Indigenous graduate students were significantly more likely to report the death of a loved one to COVID-19. One quarter of students anticipated lengthening their planned timeline to degree. Thirty percent of students reported pessimism about their career plans, and 17% planned to change their careers. Ph.D. students in particular reported lengthening their planned time to degree, with factors related to a lengthened degree timeline including a positive depression screen, changes in research projects, first-generation student status, and having attained candidacy. Students reported more support from their advisors and peers than from mid- and upper-level administrators at their institutions. Notions of administrative supportiveness were related to positive perceptions of the timeliness, inclusivity, and caring qualities of institutional communication, which together were related to maintaining original Ph.D. degree timelines. 

In Summer 2020 focus groups, students who are parents related their challenges of balancing graduate work and caregiving. Many described internal and external pressures to be productive in their work and scholarship, despite pandemic-related challenges, health complications, and racial injustice in their communities. Participants noted varied messages from faculty, departments, and institutions which alleviated or exacerbated pressure to be productive and feelings of uncertainty about the future. Graduate students, particularly those with marginalized identities, articulated the importance of their ’identities and the varying impacts of the sociopolitical context of the summer of 2020, which included the perseverance of a global pandemic, a significant increase in anti-Asian rhetoric and violence, and the multiple, high profile and widely viewed murders of unarmed Black people. 

Comparing survey responses from the same graduate students in Summer 2020 and Summer 2021 suggests that students’ experiences may have marginally improved over time, but remained largely concerning in terms of mental health, degree timelines, and career shifts. For Ph.D. students, sources of support related to their degree timelines shifted from those most immediately proximal (advisors and peers) to structural support. Results suggest that supportive practices may be linked in diverse ways to degree timeline decisions, with lengthening timelines in some cases signaling students’ receipt of needed support for degree completion. For example, relevant and timely institutional communication and high-quality health insurance were related to maintaining original degree timeline. Factors associated with lengthening timelines included those in STEM or humanities fields (compared to social and behavioral scientists), first-generation status, reporting more depressive symptoms, and the presence of a graduate student labor union on campus. 

As we emerge from the pandemic, trauma-informed graduate education can provide a framework for a more humane graduate education. Adapting the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention’s trauma guidelines, we suggest universities build three strong pillars; 1) ensure basic needs are met and trust is developed through living stipends, secure housing, food, and childcare scholarships, 2) build peer support and community through peer mentoring, writing groups, and informal faculty-student activities, and 3) empower graduate students, e.g. to decide when they are ready to complete key milestones in their degree, and for faculty to enact systemic change to make the graduate climate more inclusive and equitable.
